requirements.txt.message:
Eek - they don't publish libraries to pypi? Ah - they do:

https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-python

says pip install of both should work.

That said - that also says the library is alpha. I'm guessing this patch is about being proactive ... perhaps we should make this optional? So - don't depend on the libraries, put the imports behind a try/except and make the tracing class you made properly no-op if the libraries aren't installed? That way we can potentially support people who are interested in trying this before upstream thinks it's totally ready without making all the zuul deployers be impacted if open-telemetry changes their api in a way that breaks things?

Yes, the whole opentelemetry project is still in alpha. There were quite some API changes since the last 0.3.0 release and I figured that it would make sense to already use the 0.4.0 API.

This is anyways still WIP and just for getting a feel for how that could be integrate into Zuul.

We might also be able to influence the implementation of the opentelemetry Python lib, in case we see a use-case that can't be covered with the current set of APIs. Their main use-case is tracing of web services and Zuul is a little different :)

{{cookiecutter.repo_name}}/CONTRIBUTING..message:
I think we should change all these text with 2 line: something like

---------------------
OpenStack uses Gerrit for code review.

Any Pull requests submitted through GitHub will be ignored.

For more specific information, see the {{ cookiecutter.service }}
``contributor guide
<https://docs.openstack.org/{{ cookiecutter.repo_name }}/latest/contributor/contributing.html>``.
----------------------

IMHO that's too short ;)

Linking to the bug tracker is valid, because it tells people not to open GitHub issues.

Linking to just the project-specific contributor guide is not enough, because the most useful information is in the infra manual which is several clicks away from here.

This can probably be simplified to hard-code "openstack" instead of using a cookiecutter.repo_group now that all OpenStack projects use one common namespace (and this is the cookiecutter for OpenStack, not for projects on OpenDev more generally).
Yep, somebody could propose that as a separate cleanup. I agree the real goal would be to stop prompting for repo_group anyway, to simplify project setup.
You're right, but I'd rather remove it everywhere in a separate change than start hard-coding it piecemeal.

If we have an opportunity to improve the prose here, "will not be seen" is probably closer to the truth. We don't have any humans consistently watching our GitHub mirrors, but "ignored" has additional negative connotations that shouldn't really be ascribed to the maintainers of these projects. It's also the case that we currently have some automation to auto-close GH pull requests with a message pointing folks to contributor docs, but getting into those additional details probably isn't necessary in this document.
That wording works great for me too, sure.

"Pull requests submitted through GitHub will be terminated with extreme prejudice."

ok, ok

How about "Pull requests submitted through GitHub are not monitored"?

This part should go to the contributor guide as an entry point in introduction.html. Otherwise, we have to update the CONTRIBUTING.rst on each repo twice when infra manual is migrated to opendev.

https://docs.openstack.org/contributors/code-and-documentation/introduction.html

Yes, the Gerrit page in the Code and Documentation chapter of the OpenStack Contributors Guide is what I was suggesting in IRC. That seems like a useful entrypoint which will still cover the OpenStackisms when the Infrastructure Manual gets overhauled to exorcise its OpenStack demons.

No matter what we link here I think its going to need to change eventually once the infra-manual goes through its de-openstacking + the contrib guide goes through its de-opendeving. I tend to prefer gmann's quick start guide atm, but like I said, it will probably need to change long term. Whatever people want, this needs to be merged asap so that other projects can actually complete the goal on time.

I agree on the problem, but that just doesn't seem like a useful entry point. That page contains no information, and the most likely place people are going to end up is in the documentation contributor guide, when in fact they need to click on the sidebar. I even find myself getting disoriented.

Maybe https://docs.openstack.org/contributors/code-and-documentation/using-gerrit.html would be a better starting point?

But that does not cover the account setup etc. 

how to push patch' is way deep in that doc. We should work on contributor guide to provide a "quick start" page for "How to contribute".

I pushed a quick start page on contributor guide to list minimal steps to push first patch. That can be linked here
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/708939/

doc/source/contributor/vnfd_template_des.message:
just wondering why to change it to monitoring_params?

https://github.com/openstack/tacker/blob/484c05a898da0392680d2a55a3f33f4fcbacddfd/tacker/tosca/utils.py#L162

No, we are not using/allowing both.

Let me clarify, "parameters" and "monitoring_params" both are two deferent variables which store the same data, but their scope are different. While the "parameters" is in context of yams file, "monitoring_params" is in context of Tosca dict, which generated after parsing yams file. we are just using "parameters" in our Tosca template(yams file). And when Tosca utils parse monitoring_policy from yams file and generate a dict, it use the variable name "monitoring_params" to store "parameters". please see the [1] for reference.


[1]: https://github.com/openstack/tacker/blob/484c05a898da0392680d2a55a3f33f4fcbacddfd/tacker/tosca/utils.py#L162
I understood the intentions of these field. I restored "parameters".

I didn't recognized this code. So this means we are now allowing both of 'params' and 'monitoring_params'. But, IMO, we don't need to support both of 'params' and 'monitoring_params'. I think I can delete 'parameters' support, WDYT?
Or should we keep 'parameters' instead of 'monitoring_params'?

mistral/utils/openstack/keystone.py.message:
As mentioned in the Ie3ab512b0ab42c0f97b3099e0787f4edee08ddce :
[keystone_authtoken] group is used for keystonemiddleware to validating
token.
The new [keystone] group is used for keystoneauth to initialization
the keystone session.

So by this logic for the keystoneclient below used by the Mistral to validate trust tokens should use config from the [keystone] section.

I'm not sure if `interface` option from the [keystone_authtoken] could be used here. It's marked as deprecated: https://github.com/openstack/keystoneauth/blob/master/keystoneauth1/loading/adapter.py#L45

And keystoneclient doesn't support valid_interfaces list option.

I'd still rather avoid adding redundant config options. Can you please check how the valid_interfaces could/should be used in this case? Or we can, I guess safely, bet on using the existing interface option too. It has been deprecated for 3 years and I highly doubt it will go away any soon.

Unfortunately keystone_authtoken contains pretty much all parameters possible, including some that pertain to the session. In fact, this is not even the session but the client's parameters. Maybe the original intent was a little overengineered in the end.
As the keystone_authtoken is a quasi standard group, I believe it is best to use the value from there. E.g. what do we actually do with the values set there if we add them to the keystone group?

If the strange case the name looks like a UUID, the call will return a NotFoundException exception and then the former path will be followed:
- Retrieve the list of registers.
- Filter manually _get_one_match

As I said, this is a corner case where the function will return the same value but without the optimization.
.. if we do, this should be moved outside of the try..except block
let us ensure, that 'name' is an accepted query parameter first. Not each resource has name at all, and in some crazy cases we might even get an error from API due to that

Sorry but I don't understand this suggestion:
1) **params variable is untouched apart from the "name" parameter. I only add/delete the "name" key.
2) This test you point out in your comment is already done in cl.list() [1]. I don't need to add this check because this validation is present in the "list" method.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/master/openstack/resource.py#L1335

You are right, that we would get an exception from QueryParameters._validate. But is it better to introduce a retry mechanism instead of 2 simple lines:
```
        if 'name' in cls._query_mapping._mapping:
            params['name'] = name_or_id
```
This is especially the case, when **params contain additional attiributes

1) First we validate the query in QueryParameters._validate(). If the parameter is not accepted, we'll receive a InvalidResourceQuery exception. If "name_or_id" is for an object (DB table) without name as a parameter, we'll try always first L1458 because utils.is_uuid_like(name_or_id) will be True. OSSDK won't query using "name" if this argument is not supported.
Sorry, but I don't see the problem here. Am I missing something?

2) That's the point: we don't query using "name" if this parameter is not supported. If "name" is not supported that means "name_or_id" is an ID (UUID formatted) and L1457 will be executed. With "cls.existing" we can expect two results: the value or 404, but this is not handled by this function.

ah, that's why an except is here. Well, to be honest I am not sure:
- we get 404 if query argument is not supported (can be nearly anything from 4xx)
- it is better to fire unnecessary request when we can identify in advance whether it will bring something. I see lot of resources not supporting name. Do we really want this inefficiency?
Yes, of course. That's why I defined the exception catch in L1470. If name is not accepted, a InvalidResourceQuery will be raised. Then the same query without name is executed again.

what I mean is that instead of introducing new try/catch block for handling InvalidResourceQuery exeption (with a fallback) you can simply check, whether name is an accepted QueryParameter and add it if it is. This would be much more readable from my POV.

I have some concerns about the DB read operation done inside this method.

IMO, this DB read operation is not needed because in L1378 you are reading first the SGs for this port. My proposal is to modify "_get_security_groups_on_port" to return the requested_sgs_id and the valid_sgs. E.g.: http://paste.openstack.org/show/789528/. There you are returning the list of SG objects related to this port.

Then here you can pass this list and implement "_validate_sgs_for_port" in this way: http://paste.openstack.org/show/789529/

This will reduce the number of times we access to the DB and we'll keep the API performance similar to previous versions.

BTW, this has a collateral effect: the UT failing will pass.

ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/utils.py.message:
I guess my only concern with this patch is that don't break existing users and that this remains optional, as users have already been defining /redfish/v1/Systems/1 for a while in their system ID.

And then if we do that, do we make the "Systems" portion optional?

My impression is that 'redfish/v1' part should always be present [1]...:

  The protocol version is separate from the version of the resources or the version of the Redfish Schema supported by them.

  Each version of the Redfish protocol is strongly typed. This is accomplished using the URI of the Redfish Service in combination with the resource obtained at that URI, called the ServiceRoot.

  The root URI for this version of the Redfish protocol shall be "/redfish/v1/".

May be that's OK, from Redfish standpoint, if the vendor would mount `/redfish/v1` under some prefix URL e.g. /some/thing/redfish/v1...

WDYT?

1. http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.1.html

This does not change anything regarding the system ID, users have to keep defining it the same way they were doing before.
When not specified, sushy defaults to /redfish/v1/ for the root prefix anyways, so this should not break any compatibility afaik. I did not change the system_id and address for two reasons:
- to not break compatibility and not change the current way things work
- to address cases that do not completely comply with the standards. I did not want to assume that the root_prefix is in the system_id.

Something that could be done is to parse the root_prefix from the address parameter. Currently Sushy seems to discard whatever path is there, so we could get the root prefix from there.

I'd vote for:

- not introducing new `root_prefix` parameter
- parsing `root_prefix` out (for internal sushy consumption) from `system_id`

If we add `root_prefix`, its interplay with `system_id` (potentially pointing to some other URL prefix) would be confusing.

I would rather not make any assumption there. We're working with a system that is pre-v1 release. The only difference is that we have /<id1>/<id2>/redfish/v0/Systems/<id>. So for us the assumption where /redfish/v1 would always be present does not stand, but we still could match "/redfish/vX/Systems" and take whatever is before Systems as the root_prefix. I am just afraid of introducing a bug for some systems that do not follow this specific convention (even if it is in the standard). If you say that it is better to go this way, then I will make a new patchset. Thank you for the review @Julia and @Ilya
This means that we assume that the system_id follows the standard having the id like `<root_prefix>/Systems/<id>`. What if it does not and the system_id does not contain the root prefix ?

reference/dropping-projects.rst.message:
I think there is one other criteria that I would propose: If a project fails to respond or engage with a code-based community-wide initiative then that could trigger an inquiry.

Posit a hypothetical where a project has no contributors in this cycle as we go through the drop-py27 community goal.  If noone engages with the goal champion, the PTL is silent, and the changes proposed by the goal champion attract no core reviews then at the end of the cycle the project would have entirely failed to demonstrate the vitality to perform even minimal self-support.  And if the project depended on oslo libraries then it probably at least has broken gates if not broken code.

I think it's fine as a trigger for an investigation.

Note that the trigger isn't that they didn't *do* the goal, but that they didn't *respond in any way*.
I agree that this is a trigger for investigation but as Graham states it shouldn't be an automatic drop for a team.

While I get this as an idea, when we brought in the goal, we explicitly said that it was not going to be a stick to force projects to do goals.

We need to couch the language a bit to ensure that we don't introduce this stick.
Let's not include a list of named projects that are dead enough to drop here ;)

I'd suggest a slight wording tweak to "couldn't ever drop Keystone". This has more of an implication like "imagine if we considered dropping Keystone, haha! obviously we would never do that", where the current wording risks calling to mind the thought that Keystone is dead and we would drop it in a heartbeat if we thought we could. (Which AFAIK is not currently the case ;)

This is a bad example to me. Keystone is now a "Base service", which basically make it almost a "requirement" to OpenStack deployments. https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/base-services.html#current-list-of-base-services .

I would prefer if we say that `we won't drop projects linked to the base services, like keystone, oslo.messaging, oslo.db, etc.`.

If you meant something more, I think it would be better to clarify.

The DELETING task_state is set by the api caller before hitting the compute host. It is explicitly not guarded in the caller, so this can be set while the compute host is still booting the instance.

The semaphore on the compute host only prevents the delete from actually starting, but it's already set in the db before that.

I'm trying to figure out how to reproduce this locally with no luck. I also left a comment/question in the commit message related to this point. If we are still orphaning vifs on the host in this case for those other drivers (looks like zvm and vmware - though I'm not sure how those would work here since they aren't really running a hypervisor on the local host where the compute service is running) - maybe we should be logging something in the NotImplementedError case?

Note that in at least the case of the libvirt driver, if something fails during the spawn (well, at least if networking setup fails after we've plugged vifs) we try to unplug them as part of a rollback:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/707deb158996d540111c23afd8c916ea1c18906a/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L5738

But that doesn't mean we couldn't still get into this flow to deallocate networking *after* the driver.spawn is successful but then something else fails in the compute manager build flow.
For those drivers that don't implement unplug_vifs the bug would still exist where vifs are left plugged on the host (I guess).
Several drivers don't implement the unplug_vifs method directly on the driver - it's easy to see for yourself.

swift/proxy/controllers/base.py.message:
Should we just extend this to catch GreenletExit?  I wonder why we don't have to close/cancel the connection here - does letting it fall out of scope not "work"?  We certainly use close_swift_conn a lot below...

I'd guess mostly this is probably where the "leave it running" strategy currently normally falls into.  In that case the error limiting is probably healthy.  But I could also imagine some cases where it's slow but "works" and we still process the "update timing" code.

So here's my testing setup:

* Create a new, empty container.
* Stop all container-servers, then restart just *one* of them.
* Run nc on one or more of the stopped-container-server ports; something like

 ncat -lk --max-conns 1024 localhost 6031 >/dev/null &

In one window, watch the open connections like

 watch -n .1 'lsof -i TCP | grep 6031'

In another, restart proxies (to make sure nothing's error-limited) and issue a bunch of requests like

 swift-init proxy restart && ( for i in {1..100}; do curl http://saio:8090/v1/AUTH_test/c >&2 & done; wait ) 2> /dev/null

/COMMIT_MSG.message: lock is required to synchronized the CLOUD_0 client access as those may occur via the threads created per subcloud?
What happens if two greenthreads attempt to read from a particular socket?

Yes, the client object instance is created and cached per region (include CLOUD_0), and different threads (i.e. sync thread and alarm update thread) could access the same client object simultaneously. By default, the eventlet prevents multiple readers on the same client socket. The lock is to ensure that only one greenthread can read any particular socket.

Some additional testcases (maybe you have done these already):
- add/delete subclouds
- managed subcloud goes offline/online (power off/on)
- managed subcloud goes offline/online (networking interruption)

The advantage is that each thread audit, orch, fm in a subcloud dont each have update the client when the token expires or when a new subcloud is added.

Why isn't it safe for multiple threads to do a get_dns? And if we really can't avoid this, shouldn't we be using oslo_concurrency and handling this by adding a decorator to each method we need to protect?
Yes.
The client lock is per instance based which means only serialize the sysinv request to the same subcloud.

By default, the eventlet does not allow simultaneous read on the client socket. It would throw 'Second simultaneous read' exception. 

threading.lock() is still used to guard for concurrent operations. Do you think oslo_concurrency.lockutils.synchronized optimizes the CPU resource usage?

The problem with the current set of changes is that sharing the clients across all greenthreads and doing locking here is going to serialize all the operations for all the greenthreads. So if we have 1000 subclouds auditing the DNS config, they will be stuck doing GET from sysinv one at a time. In that case there isn't much point in having separate sync/audit threads for each subcloud. I think we need to have a cached client per subcloud (i.e. per sync thread) and avoid doing any of this locking when calling the clients.
Right - my mistake. So there is a global list of clients but a different client per subcloud.

Yes, it can be None still. It happens e.g. in case of creation of SG rule, when _check_for_duplicate_rules() is called and that calls get_security_group() and finally get_security_groups() - see L206 in this file. There is admin_context used as argument and it has no tenant_id.

I'm Ok with this code.

nit: But shouldn't we try to capture the keystone event of project creation instead? We have plenty of those calls in this module.
I don't think we can do it now. If that would be possible, probably cleaning of resources after project deletion would be also easier to implement :)
That was just a comment, this is out of scope.

Would we like to call _ensure_default_security_group here too?
The bug is about a case where list_security_group_rules are called before accessing any security groups. The similar case happens for this method.

But this method is never used. See http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=get_security_group_rules_count&i=nope&files=&repos=

I will propose a patch to remove it.
Agree
You are right: http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=get_security_group_rules_count&i=nope&files=&repos=
Patch https://review.opendev.org/709140 proposed :)
